children.text: Indicator 1: Analyze U.S. historical eras to determine connections and cause/effect relationships in reference to chronology.
(Application) Use timelines from birth to present to relate self and family to changes over time.
(Application) Place important historical events in the order in which they occurred.
(Comprehension) Compare features of modernday living (food, shelter, clothing, transportation) to those of the past.
(Comprehension) Describe ways historical figures contributed to modernday life.
(Knowledge) Identify the obstacles and successes of the early settlers and Native Americans in creating communities.
(Comprehension) Explain factors affecting the growth and expansion of South Dakota.
(Knowledge) Identify basic environmental, economic, cultural, and population issues of concern to South Dakota.
(Comprehension) Differentiate the lifestyles of various Native American tribes.
(Knowledge) Identify key early American explorers and their accomplishments.
(Knowledge) Identify influential people and key events during the American Revolution.
(Knowledge) Identify the key changes leading to and resulting from growth and invention in the U.S. between the Revolution and 1865.
(Analysis) Relate events and outcomes of the American Revolution to sources of conflict, roles of key individuals and battles, and political documents.
(Comprehension) Describe the unfolding of westward expansion and reform movements in the United States.
(Comprehension) Describe the sources of conflict, key individuals, battles, and political documents of the Civil War period.
(Comprehension) Summarize the political and social changes in the United States during Reconstruction.
(Analysis) Explain the cause-effect relationships and legacy that distinguish significant historical periods from Reconstruction to the present.
(Application) Relate previously learned information of these time periods to the context of succeeding time periods.
(Evaluation) Relate the causes and consequences of historical events to subsequent events and their legacy in current conditions.
Indicator 2: Evaluate the influence/impact of various cultures, values, philosophies, and religions on the development of the U.S.
(Comprehension) Connect people and events honored in commemorative holidays.
(Comprehension) Compare ways different cultures shared traditions.
Indicator 2: Evaluate the influence/impact of various cultures, philosophies, and religions on the development of the U.S.
(Knowledge) Describe characteristics of a community.
(Knowledge) Identify a community's culture and history.
(Knowledge) Describe the impact of significant turning points on the development of the culture in South Dakota.
(Comprehension) Explain the effects of the Native American conflicts and establishment of reservations on the Native American culture.
(Comprehension) Describe the influence of notable South Dakotans on the development of our state.
(Knowledge) Identify the reasons that led to the development of colonial America.
(Knowledge) Describe the political relationship between the colonies and England.
(Comprehension) Compare and contrast social, economic, and philosophical differences between the North and the South.
(Analysis) Explain the impact of the American Revolution on American philosophies.
(Analysis) Summarize the influence of westward expansion and reform movements on American culture, philosophies, and religions.
(Analysis) Summarize the impacts of the Civil War on American culture and philosophies.
(Analysis) Describe the impact of various cultures and philosophies on the U.S. during Reconstruction.
(Analysis) Describe the causes and effects of interactions between the U.S. government and Native American cultures.
(Application) Describe the causes and effects of cultural, economic, religious, political, and social reform movements on the development of the U.S.
(Knowledge) Identify the influences of local groups on settlement patterns of South Dakota and the Great Plains Region.
(Evaluation) Evaluate the significance of interactions between the U.S. government and diverse cultures in relation to cultural preservation versus cultural assimilation.
Indicator 1: Analyze historical eras of world history to determine connections and cause/effect relationships in reference to chronology.
(Knowledge) Identify events as past or present.
(Comprehension) Describe how wars affected South Dakotans.
(Knowledge) Identify the causes and effects of European exploration and their impact.
(Comprehension) Describe the impact other countries had on the United States through exploration, trade, and conflict.
(Analysis) Explain the development of society during the Stone Age.
(Analysis) Explain the development of the River Valley Civilizations based on their geographic locations.
(Analysis) Explain the development of Mediterranean civilizations.
(Analysis) Explain the development of the Middle Eastern civilizations.
(Analysis) Explain the development of the African empires.
(Analysis) Explain the development of the Mesoamerican/Andean empires.
(Analysis) Summarize the political, economic, and social changes that occurred during the Middle Ages.
(Analysis) Explain the cause-effect relationships and legacy that distinguish significant historical periods from the Renaissance to the present.
(Evaluation) Relate the causes and consequences of historical events to subsequent events and their legacy in current conditions.
Indicator 2: Evaluate the interaction of world cultures and civilizations, philosophies, and religions.
(Comprehension) Compare holidays celebrated in different countries.
(Knowledge) List the reasons why people immigrate.
(Knowledge) Describe influences of European cultures on South Dakota communities.
(Knowledge) Identify key conflicts with other cultures of the world and the effect they had on the United States physically, economically, and socially.
(Analysis) Describe how the structure of Stone Age society changed because of the agricultural revolution.
(Comprehesion) Identify the cultural contributions of the River Valley civilizations.
(Comprehension) Identify the cultural contributions of the Mediterranean civilizations.
(Comprehension) Identify the cultural contributions of the Middle Eastern civilizations.
(Comprehension) Identify the cultural contributions of the African empires.
(Comprehension) Identify the cultural contributions of the Mesoamerican/Andean empires.
(Comprehension) Identify the cultural contributions of the Middle Ages.
(Comprehension) Define the key distinguishing features of significant cultural, economic, and political philosophies in relation to the other.
(Analysis) Describe the emergence, rise, impact, and role of significant cultural, economic, and political events and philosophies.
Indicator 1: Analyze information from geographic representation, tools, and technology to define location, place, and region.
(Application) Use map colors to recognize land and water.
(Comprehension) Compare the globe and a map as models of the Earth.
(Application) Demonstrate familiarity with the layout of their own school.
(Application) Construct a simple map using a map key and at least three symbols.
(Application) Use a picture map to locate an address.
(Knowledge) Identify a continent as a large land mass and an ocean as a large body of water.
(Application) Construct a simple aerial view map of the classroom using a map key/legend and at least five symbols.
(Knowledge) Use simple map reading skills to identify the map title, label four directions on a compass rose, and interpret the symbols of a map key/legend.
(Knowledge) Identify and use map components.
(Knowledge) Identify locations in a community by using grid systems.
(Application) Locate the seven continents, four major oceans, major United States landforms, and state boundaries on a map or globe.
(Comprehension) Compare regions of the United States to South Dakota.
(Application) Locate major South Dakota geographical and political features.
(Application) Locate major United States political features.
(Application) Apply longitude and latitude to find absolute locations on a map and globe.
(Application) Compare maps of different types and scales.
(Application) Select appropriate resources, data services, and geographic tools to interpret information.
(Application) Apply location, direction, size, and/or shape to maps.
(Application) Identify characteristics of various locations, places, and regions.
(Application) Identify population distribution, growth rates, and characteristics of human populations.
(Application) Use resources, data services, and geographic tools that generate and interpret information.
(Application) Interpret geographic representations when given information about places and events.
(Evaluation) Evaluate and select resources, data services, and geographic tools that generate and interpret information.
(Synthesis) Construct geographic representations when given information about places and events
Indicator 2: Analyze the relationships among the natural environments, the movement of peoples, and the development of societies.
(Knowledge) Identify reasons people move and how it affects their communities.
(Knowledge) Describe how the resources of various regions and the state of South Dakota affected the growth of each.
(Comprehension) Describe how climate and geography influenced the way of life of Native American tribes and the movement and activities of settlers.
(Comprehension) Explain explorers' discoveries in the New World.
(Application) Identify natural environmental changes that impact regions and settlement patterns.
(Application) Identify how humans impact and are affected by the natural environment.
(Application) Describe the impact of the natural environment on settlement patterns.
(Application) Identify how human migration impacts politics, the environment, and regions.
(Analysis) Identify and explain the impact of the natural environment on human settlement patterns.
(Comprehension) Explain how humans interact with their environment.
(Analysis) Explain how human migration impacts local and global politics, environment, economies, societies, and regions.
(Knowledge) Identify the main characteristics of cultural geography.
(Analysis) Analyze and articulate the fundamental role that place characteristics and environments have played in history.
(Evaluation) Evaluate how humans interact with their environment.
(Synthesis) Investigate how past and present trends of human migration impact both local and global politics, environment, economies, and societies.
(Analysis) Compare and contrast the differing characteristics in developing and developed countries.
Indicator 1: Analyze forms and purposes of government in relationship to the needs of citizens and societies including the impact of historical events, ideals, and documents.
(Knowledge) Identify American symbols and landmarks.
(Comprehension) Explain the difference between rules and laws.
(Analysis) Identify why laws are needed in a community and why there are legal consequences for lawbreakers.
(Comprehension) Explain the basic political roles of leaders in the larger community.
(Comprehension) Explain human relationships and roles in a community
(Comprehension) Recognize government agencies and their roles in a community.
(Comprehension) Explain the meaning and importance of the Constitution and Declaration of Independence.
(Comprehension) Explain why communities have rules and laws.
(Comprehension) Describe the way the government provides for the needs of its citizens.
(Knowledge) Describe key events related to South Dakota's entry into statehood.
(Knowledge) Define basic differences between various forms of government.
(Comprehension) Define and describe the roles of democratic government of the United States.
(Application) Relate forms of governments to their civilizations.
(Synthesis) Identify relationships of events, ideals, and written documents to changes in civilizations.
(Analysis) Describe how government impacts the characteristics of place.
(Comprehension) Identify historical events that impacted individual governments.
(Comprehension) Describe the basic structure of government adopted through compromises by the Constitutional Convention.
(Application) Describe the relationship of government to citizens and groups during the Westward Expansion.
(Application) Describe the successes and problems of the government under the Articles of Confederation.
(Comprehension) Describe the impact of the Civil War on the United States government.
(Analysis) Explain the characteristics of various forms of government.
(Evaluation) Determine the influence of major historical documents and ideals on the formation of the United States government.
(Knowledge) Identify the principles of the American Constitution.
(Comprehension) Explain the principles of American democracy.
(Comprehension) Describe the state, local, and tribal governments with emphasis on their structures, functions, and powers.
(Application) Describe the elements of how U.S. foreign policy is created.
(Evaluation) Compare the United States' political systems with those of major democratic and authoritarian nations in terms of the structures and powers of political institutions.
Indicator 2: Analyze the constitutional rights and responsibilities of United States citizens.
(Knowledge) List rules in different groups for different situations.
(Knowledge) Identify the attributes of good citizenship.
(Application) Describe the meaning of majority rule and its related function in a democracy.
(Knowledge) Identify the rights and responsibilities of citizenship in students' own communities.
(Knowledge) Describe the actions and rights of a responsible citizen.
(Comprehension) Describe how volunteerism helped develop the United States.
(Evaluation) Recognize how historical civilizations influence the rights and responsibilities of citizens today.
(Synthesis) Describe how citizens impact social and political issues.
(Comprehension) Describe the fundamental liberties and rights stated in the first 15 amendments of the Constitution.
(Application) Describe the means of influencing and/or participating in a republic.
(Comprehension) Interpret the meaning of basic constitutional rights guaranteed to citizens.
(Comprehension) Describe the process of naturalization.
(Analysis) Enumerate the basic constitutional rights guaranteed to citizens and their related impacts on society.
(Analysis) Analyze and explain the purpose of politics/political activity and the related implications for United States citizens.
(Analysis) Identify various issues involving individual rights and responsibilities in relation to the general welfare.

(Analysis) Analyze campaigns for national, state, and local elective office, including the nominating process, campaign funding and spending, and the influence of media coverage, including campaign advertising and public opinion polls.
Indicator 1: Analyze the role and relationships of economic systems on the development, utilization, and availability of resources in societies.
(Knowledge) Identify occupations with simple descriptions of work.
(Knowledge) Identify the difference between basic needs (food, clothing, and shelter) and wants (luxuries).
(Comprehension) Describe the role of money in everyday life.
(Knowledge) Define goods and services.
(Comprehension) Explain choices families have to make when buying goods and services.
(Knowledge) Identify the differences between natural resources and human resources and how they are used.
(Comprehension) Explain the importance of making informed decisions about spending, borrowing, and saving.
(Comprehension) Explain ways producers use resources to produce goods and services.
(Knowledge) Identify goods and services available in the students' communities.
(Knowledge) Identify the relationships between taxation and government service.
(Comprehension) Describe how the economic needs of South Dakotans and people in other regions of the United States have been met.
(Comprehension) Define profit and loss and explain how businesses take risks in order to make a profit.
(Knowledge) Identify how government pays for the goods and services it provides.
(Comprehension) Describe the role of trading in early United States history.
(Knowledge) Describe examples of various institutions that make up economic systems.
(Comprehension) Describe key economic events prior to 1865 leading to the expansion of territories in the United States.
(Application) Explain societies' attempts to satisfy their basic needs and wants by utilizing resources.
(Knowledge) Identify basic economic systems through the Middle Ages.
(Application) Identify the effects of economic systems on society.
(Analysis) Explain how the availability of resources provides for or challenges human activities.
(Application) Describe how economic activity affects standard of living.
(Application) Describe the role of trade barriers and agreements in the global economy.
(Analysis) Describe how technology affects the economic development of places and regions.
(Application) Describe the relationship between government and economic systems in different countries.
(Comprehension) Identify economic support for America during conflicts.
(Analysis) Describe how westward expansion was motivated by economic gain.
(Analysis) Describe the impact of technology and industrialization on mid- 1800s America.
(Comprehension) Outline the economic effects of Reconstruction in the United States.
(Analysis) Compare the characteristics of the world's traditional, command, market, and mixed economies. [U.S. History, World History, Geography, Civics (Government)]
(Analysis) Explain how scarcity and surplus affect the basic questions of what, how, how much, and for whom to produce. [Geography, Civics (Government)]
(Application) Explain the role of money and the structure of the banking system of the U.S. [U.S. History, Civics (Government)]
(Evaluation) Explain the impact of labor and governmental policies on the economy of the United States. [U.S. History, Civics (Government)]
(Application) Use graphs to illustrate changes in economic trends. [U.S. History, Civics (Government)]
(Synthesis) Explain basic elements of trade and its impact on the U.S. economy. [Civics (Government)]
(Synthesis) Differentiate the patterns and networks of global economic interdependence in relation to local, regional, and world economies.
(Analysis) Analyze graphs to determine changes in supply and demand and their effects on price and quality.
(Evaluation) Compare and contrast the economic systems of foreign countries with the market system of the United States.
(Analysis) Describe methods used to measure domestic output, national income, and price level.
(Analysis) Describe the effect of fluctuation in national output and its relationship to unemployment and inflation.
